eu.trentorise.opendata.commons

Class APeriodOfTime

  • java.lang.Object
    • eu.trentorise.opendata.commons.APeriodOfTime
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    PeriodOfTime

    @Value.Immutable
@Beta
abstract class APeriodOfTime
extends Object
    A time interval, which may be bounded, unbounded, partially or completely unknown. Allows storing automatically parsed dates, and also the original strings from which they originate.

    This class implements dct:PeriodOfTime in the DCAT AP 1.1 flavor, adapting it to possibly dirty data. This abstract class is used to generate the immutable PeriodOfTime.

    Available fields

    Automatically parsed dates are stored in startDate and endDate fields

    Original unclean/unparseable data can be stored in rawString field.

    Date format

    Dates are stored in an extended ISO 8061 format, where:
    • If a start or end date is known, it is stored as ISO 8061 format with a level of precision faithful to the original format (so if you have day precision avoid specifying seconds).
    • If the interval is known to be unbounded with certainty, one or both the dates are stored as the empty string "".
    • If the interval might be unbounded, one of the dates is stored as a question mark '?'.
    • If the interval is completely unknown, both dates will be represented as a question mark '?'.

    Since:
    1.1
    See Also:
    APeriodOfTime

    • Method Detail

      • getStartDate

        @Value.Default
public String getStartDate()
        The start date and time. This field MAY be the result of some automated processing, but its value is assumed to be faithful to the original. Original date precision should be preserved (so i.e. if it is a day, don't specify seconds).
        • If the date is known, it is stored in ISO8061 format. The start of the period should be understood as the start of the date, hour, minute etc. given (e.g. starting at midnight at the beginning of the day if the value is a day),
        • An empty value indicates the interval is unbounded, so there's no start.
        • A value holding a question mark '?' means it is not known if exists a start date at all.
        See Also:
        getRawString() field for the original value.

      • getEndDate

        @Value.Default
public String getEndDate()
        The end date and time. This field MAY be the result of some automated processing, but its value is assumed to be faithful to the original. Original date precision should be preserved (so i.e. if it is a day, don't specify seconds).
        • If the date is known, it is stored in ISO8061 format. the end of the period should be understood as the end of the date, hour, minute etc. given (e.g. ending at midnight at the end of the day if the value is a day),
        • An empty value indicates the interval is unbounded, so there's no end.
        • A value holding a question mark '?' means it is not known if exists an end date at all.
        See Also:
        getRawString() field for the original value.

      • getRawString

        @Value.Default
public String getRawString()
        The original period of time. If it was already a String, it is reported here as is, otherwise this value will be made by joining the serialized form of the two parts, separated by SEP separator.

      • isRealDate

        public static boolean isRealDate(Date date,
                 boolean start)
        Returns true if date is not null and its milliseconds are not extremal ones (Long.MIN_VALUE or Long.MAX_VALUE)

      • check

        @Value.Check
protected void check()

      • toFormattedString

        public String toFormattedString()
        An interval of time in string format. It may represents, either:
        • A bounded interval where dates are formatted following ISO 8601 Date and Time interval string format i.e. "2007-03-01T13:00:00Z/2008-05-11T15:30:00Z". NOTE: ISO 8601 only allows bounded intervals
        • An unbounded interval where one of the two dates is represented as the empty string. Interval shall either begin with '/' or end with '/'. The existing date string will be formatted following ISO 8601 Date and Time format. NOTE: unbounded intervals are not part of ISO 8601 standard.
        • An interval with a known start or end, but it is not known whether interval is unbounded or bounded. To represent this, one of the two dates will be represented as the question mark '?', so interval shall either begin with "?/" or end with "/?". The other date will be formatted following ISO 8601 Date and Time format. NOTE: partially unknown intervals are not part of ISO 8601 standard.
        • An unknown interval, represented by the string "?/?" Notice the empty string is not allowed. NOTE: unknown intervals are not part of ISO 8601 standard.
        See Also:
        getRawString()

      • joinRawDates

        public static String joinRawDates(String startDate,
                  String endDate)

      • of

        public static PeriodOfTime of(String rawString)
        Factory method that just fills rawString field. startDate and endDate are set to '?'
        Parameters:
        rawString - a temporal interval with unknown formatting

      • of

        public static PeriodOfTime of(String startDate,
              String endDate)
        Factory method that fills all fields. rawString field is filled with the two provided dates joined with string SEP. For parameter meaning, see toFormattedString().
        Parameters:
        startDate - an ISO8061 date, a question mark '?', or the empty string.
        endDate - an ISO8061 date, a question mark '?', or the empty string.
